column4: Orbin: the Indigo comes with 500 Mhz clockspeed and 768 MB RAM. I will give Xubuntu a try then. Ubuntu was frozen solid ;-)
that's more than enough for Ubuntu
i've had Ubuntu running well on a toilet-seat iBook@366Mhz.
how much swap did you allow for? what apps did you install?
the most recent Ubuntu shouyld be faster than the most recent OSX by a wide margin
if it won't boot from CD, maybe there are hardware issues?
smells like a bad burn or bad hardware
I heard the issue about the burn speed before for the iMac. Why is that? (just wanting to learn)
the CDs are not very fault tolerant. a single 1 instead of a 0 can be fatal. but that is rarely the case for, say, a movie file.
true. i will burn a new live CD image this way.
Ubuntu ships with the xorg X11, not xfree
exactly. On the iMac xorg freezes. I found that out while installing Debian Sarge. Sarge still uses xfree, but when upgrading to Sid it froze like Ubuntu. xserver-xorg seems to be the culprit
are these clean installs, or aer you trying to overwite one X11 implementation with another and expecting no problems? ;)
Ubuntu Dapper on the iMac was a clean install. Sarge was a clean install, from Sarge to Sid was an upgrade
one of the solutions that was suggested was not to use the FBDev option. I was curious whether someone had experience with it.
the solution is to abandon the deprecated XFree86 for X.org ;)
sorry but that is exactly what is causing the problem on the iMac. X.org is freezing, not xfree86
probably because you have old bits of XFree lying around
how is that possible with a clean install of Dapper?
it is possible because you probably did not reformat the partition on which Linux lives.
x.org works perfectly well on PPC. i have installed it countless times on Apple hardware. x.org itself is not the problem.
